settings-general.title: General Settings Overview
settings-general.body:
What are General Settings?

These settings control site-wide identity used in structured data (schema) and social metadata. They help search engines and social platforms understand your brand and display your pages consistently.

Tip: Set these once, then keep them stable. Frequent changes can cause inconsistent previews and schema signals.

What you configure here

  • Organization / Site Name (used in schema and sometimes social templates)
  • Logo URL (used in schema and social previews)
  • XML Sitemap link (so you can submit it to search engines)
  • Default Robots Settings (site-wide indexing + link-following defaults)
Important: These settings help with clarity and consistency. They do not guarantee indexing or improve rankings by themselves.

site-name.title: Organization / Site Name
site-name.body:
What does this do?

This is your brand or organization name. It can appear in:

  • Schema.org markup (Organization / WebSite)
  • Social previews (when templates use site name)
  • Default titles (if you use title templates)

Best practice

  • Use your official brand name (exact spelling and capitalization)
  • Keep it consistent with your website header, social profiles, and Google Business Profile (if you have one)
  • Avoid keyword stuffing (e.g., "ZenDigitalWorld | Quotes | Greetings | Books")
Recommendation: If your site name is "Zendigitalworld", enter exactly that.

logo-url.title: Logo URL
logo-url.body:
What does this do?

Your logo may be used in:

  • Organization schema (brand identification)
  • Social previews (some platforms use it in cards)
  • Rich results (only if search engines choose to show brand/logo)

Recommended logo formats

  • Best overall: square logo (e.g., 512√ó512 or 600√ó600)
  • Also ok: horizontal brand mark (your UI recommends 600√ó60)
  • Use a clean image, readable at small sizes
  • Prefer a transparent background (PNG) if possible
Note: The URL should be a publicly accessible image URL on your live site (not localhost) for real search engines and social platforms.

sitemap-info.title: XML Sitemap
sitemap-info.body:
What is a sitemap?

An XML sitemap is a list of your important URLs. Search engines use it to discover new and updated pages more efficiently.

What this section shows

  • Sitemap URL: the sitemap your site is currently exposing
  • View Sitemap: opens the sitemap so you can confirm it loads
  • Submission links: shortcuts to Google Search Console and Bing Webmaster Tools

How to use it (recommended)

  1. Click View Sitemap and confirm the URL loads without errors
  2. Verify your site in Google Search Console and/or Bing Webmaster Tools
  3. Submit the exact sitemap URL shown here in their Sitemaps section
Tip: Use the sitemap URL displayed on this page. Different setups can use different sitemap paths.
Reality check: A sitemap helps discovery, but it does not guarantee indexing or rankings.

default-robots.title: Default Robots Settings
default-robots.body:
What are Robots settings?

Robots settings control your site-wide defaults for:

  • Indexing ‚Äî whether search engines may show pages in search results
  • Following ‚Äî whether search engines may follow links on pages

Default Indexing

  • Index: allows pages to appear in search results (recommended for most public sites)
  • NoIndex: prevents pages from appearing in search results

Default Following

  • Follow: allows search engines to follow links (recommended for most sites)
  • NoFollow: tells search engines not to follow links on pages
Critical warning: If you set Default Indexing = NoIndex, you are telling search engines to hide your entire site from search results. This is usually only correct for staging/dev sites.

Recommended defaults (most public sites)

  • Default Indexing: Index
  • Default Following: Follow

Page-level overrides

Even with safe defaults, you can still set specific pages to NoIndex (e.g., thank-you pages, login pages) using per-page SEO controls.

Tip: If you're unsure, use Index + Follow as defaults and apply NoIndex only to specific pages when needed.

gsc-verification.title: Google Search Console Verification
gsc-verification.body:
What Is Google Search Console Verification?

Verification proves to Google Search Console that you own or manage this website. Once verified, you gain access to:

  • Search performance analytics and ranking data
  • Indexing status and crawl error reports
  • Page experience insights (Core Web Vitals)
  • Sitemap submission and URL inspection tools
  • Manual action notifications
üí° Important: Verification does NOT improve your search rankings. It only gives you access to Google's webmaster data and tools.

How it works

Each search engine gives you a unique code. This plugin outputs that code as a <meta> tag in your site‚Äôs <head>. When you click Verify, the search engine checks your homepage source for that tag.

Step-by-Step Google Verification

  1. Go to Google Search Console and add your property
  2. Choose the HTML tag verification method
  3. Copy only the value inside content="..." (not the full meta tag)
  4. Paste it into the Google verification field in this plugin and click Save Settings
  5. Return to Google Search Console and click Verify
Common mistake: Don‚Äôt paste the entire <meta> tag. Paste only the content value (the long string).

Google Search Console (GSC)

Google provides a tag like:

<meta name="google-site-verification" content="abc123xyz456" />

Paste only: abc123xyz456

Tip: If you‚Äôre using the Domain property in GSC, Google may require DNS verification instead. This meta-tag method is typically for URL-prefix properties.

Troubleshooting Google Verification

  • Clear cache: If you use caching/CDN, purge cache after saving.
  • Check page source: Open your homepage, view source, and confirm the meta tag is present in <head>.
  • Avoid duplicates: Don‚Äôt add the same verification code in multiple plugins (it can create confusion).
  • Staging sites: If your site is globally set to noindex, verification can still work, but indexing won‚Äôt happen until noindex is removed.

After Successful Verification

  • Submit your XML sitemap to help Google find all your pages
  • Monitor indexing status and fix crawl errors
  • Track search performance and click-through rates
  • Set up email alerts for critical issues
  • Use URL inspection tool to test individual pages
üí° Pro Tip: Google Search Console data has a 3-day delay. Don't expect immediate results after making SEO changes.

bing-verification.title: Bing Webmaster Tools Verification
bing-verification.body:
What Is Bing Verification?

Bing verification proves to Bing Webmaster Tools that you own or manage this website. Once verified, you gain access to:

  • Indexing and crawl reports for Bing and Yahoo
  • Sitemap submission and crawl control
  • Search performance data
  • SEO and site health insights

How Bing Verification Works

Bing provides a unique verification code that must be added as a <meta> tag inside your site's <head> section.

This plugin automatically inserts the meta tag for you.

Step-by-Step Verification Process

  1. Go to Bing Webmaster Tools
  2. Add your website (or select an existing site)
  3. Choose the HTML Meta Tag verification method
  4. Copy ONLY the content value provided by Bing
  5. Paste the value into the Bing verification field in this plugin
  6. Click Save Settings
  7. Return to Bing Webmaster Tools and click Verify

Example: Bing Meta Tag

<meta name="msvalidate.01" content="ABC123DEF456" />

You only need to copy: ABC123DEF456

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Do not paste the entire meta tag. Paste only the value inside content="".

Why Bing Matters

  • Powers Bing Search
  • Used by Yahoo Search
  • Feeds results to DuckDuckGo and other platforms
  • Often easier and faster indexing than Google
üí° Note: Verification does NOT improve rankings. It only unlocks access to Bing‚Äôs webmaster reports and tools.

After Verification

  • Submit your sitemap
  • Monitor crawl errors
  • View search queries and impressions
  • Manage crawl rate and indexing preferences

yandex-verification.title: Yandex Webmaster Verification
yandex-verification.body:
What Is Yandex Verification?

Yandex verification confirms that you own or manage this website, allowing access to Yandex Webmaster tools.

When Yandex Verification Is Useful

  • You target users in Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Kazakhstan, or CIS regions
  • Your content is multilingual or region-specific
  • You want visibility insights for Yandex search

How Yandex Verification Works

Yandex provides a unique verification code that must be added as a <meta> tag in your site‚Äôs <head>.

This plugin automatically adds the tag for you.

Step-by-Step Verification Process

  1. Go to Yandex Webmaster
  2. Add your website

  4. Copy ONLY the verification code value
  5. Paste the value into the Yandex verification field in this plugin
  6. Click Save Settings
  7. Return to Yandex Webmaster and click Verify

Example: Yandex Meta Tag

You only need to copy: abcdef123456

Important Notes About Yandex

  • Verification is optional for most global websites
  • Not required if you do not target Yandex users
  • Yandex uses different ranking and crawling rules than Google
üí° Note: Verification does NOT influence rankings. It only enables access to Yandex Webmaster data.

  • Manage crawl settings for Yandex bots

indexnow-protocol.title: Understanding IndexNow
indexnow-protocol.body:
What is IndexNow?

IndexNow is a protocol that lets your site notify participating search engines when a URL is created, updated, or deleted. This reduces the waiting time for discovery compared to relying only on crawling.

Plain meaning: Your site ‚Äúpings‚Äù search engines when something changes, so they know what to check next.

How it works

  1. You publish, update, or delete a page
  2. This plugin sends the changed URL(s) to an IndexNow endpoint
  3. Participating search engines can pick up those URLs for faster crawling
  4. Search engines may crawl the URL sooner than usual

Participating search engines

Commonly supported via IndexNow:

  • ‚úÖ Bing (Microsoft)
  • ‚úÖ Yandex
  • ‚úÖ Seznam.cz (Czech Republic)
  • ‚úÖ Naver (South Korea)

Not supported:

  • ‚ùå Google (Google does not use IndexNow)

What IndexNow helps with

  • Faster discovery of new or updated pages (especially on Bing and other participating engines)
  • Less wasted crawling (engines don‚Äôt need to re-check unchanged pages as often)
  • Better for time-sensitive content (news, deals, events, frequent updates)

What IndexNow does NOT do

Important realities:
  • IndexNow does not guarantee indexing
  • IndexNow does not improve rankings by itself
  • Search engines still decide whether/when to crawl and index
  • You still need Google Search Console for Google-related indexing workflows

API key and verification file

IndexNow requires proof that you control the site. When you enable IndexNow, this plugin generates an API key and creates a verification file at:

https://yoursite.com/<your-api-key>.txt

Participating search engines may check for this file before accepting URL notifications.

Should you enable it?

Enable IndexNow if:

  • You publish or update content frequently (weekly or more)
  • You care about Bing visibility or non-Google search engines
  • You run time-sensitive pages (offers, announcements, event pages)

Skip IndexNow if:

  • You publish rarely (e.g., monthly) and don‚Äôt need faster discovery
  • Your only focus is Google
  • Your site is still in staging / not meant to be indexed yet
Best practice: Keep your sitemap enabled and submitted in Google Search Console and Bing Webmaster Tools. IndexNow is a complement, not a replacement.

social-media-tags.title: Social Media & Open Graph Tags
social-media-tags.body:
What Are Open Graph Tags?

Open Graph (OG) tags control how your pages appear when shared on social media platforms. They define:

  • Preview image
  • Title and description
  • URL and site name

Platform Support

Open Graph is used by:

  • Facebook
  • LinkedIn
  • Pinterest
  • WhatsApp
  • Discord
  • Telegram
  • Slack
  • Most other social and messaging apps

Twitter/X uses:

  • Twitter Cards (similar to Open Graph but with different meta tags)
  • Falls back to Open Graph if Twitter Card tags are missing

Default Open Graph Image

This image is used when:

  • A page doesn't have a featured image
  • A page is shared on social media
  • No other image is explicitly set

Recommended size: 1200√ó630 pixels

Why this size? It works well on Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, Discord, and most platforms without cropping.

Twitter Username

Setting your Twitter/X username enables "Twitter Card" previews with large images when your content is shared on Twitter/X.

Format: Just the username (without @)

Example: clarityfirstseo not @clarityfirstseo

Facebook App ID

This is optional and only needed if you want:

  • Facebook Insights for your website
  • Advanced analytics on how your content performs on Facebook
  • Validation tools in Facebook's Sharing Debugger

Most sites can skip this.

Theme Color

Some platforms (Discord, Telegram) display a colored strip or embed border using the theme-color meta tag. This is purely cosmetic.

Example: #2271b1 (WordPress blue)

üí° Tip: Use your brand's primary color for consistency.

Do Social Tags Affect SEO?

No. Google does not use Open Graph or Twitter Card tags for rankings. However, better social previews can lead to:

  • More clicks from social media
  • More traffic to your site
  • Better brand recognition

‚ö†Ô∏è Reality Check: Social tags affect how your links look when shared. They do not improve your Google rankings directly.

Testing Your Social Tags

Use these tools to preview how your pages will look when shared:

  • Facebook: Sharing Debugger
  • Twitter/X: Card Validator
  • LinkedIn: Post Inspector

schema-structured-data.title: Schema & Structured Data
schema-structured-data.body:
What Is Schema.org Markup?

Schema (structured data) is code that describes your content in a machine-readable format. It helps search engines understand:

  • What your page is about
  • What type of content it contains (article, business, event, recipe, etc.)
  • Key details (name, address, phone, hours, reviews, etc.)

Why Use Schema?

Benefits:

  • Helps search engines understand your content better
  • May enable rich results (stars, breadcrumbs, business info) in search
  • Improves content clarity for voice assistants and AI

‚ö†Ô∏è Important Reality: Schema does NOT guarantee rich results or better rankings. Google may choose to display rich results if it finds the schema useful and the content high-quality, but there's no guarantee.

Organization Schema

This markup describes your business or brand:

  • Official name
  • Logo
  • Social media profiles
  • Website URL

Most sites should enable Organization schema ‚Äî it's simple and helps establish brand identity.

Breadcrumbs Schema

Breadcrumbs show page hierarchy (e.g., Home > Blog > Article Title).

Enable if:

  • Your site has multiple levels (categories, subcategories, pages)
  • You want breadcrumbs to appear in Google search results (if Google chooses to display them)

Skip if:

  • Your site is simple (only homepage and a few pages)
  • You don't use category/taxonomy structures

üí° Tip: Use Google's Rich Results Test to validate your schema after setup.

Schema Does Not Guarantee Rankings

Schema helps search engines understand your content. It may lead to better visibility through rich results, but it does NOT directly improve rankings. High-quality content, good user experience, and proper technical SEO still matter most.

local-biz-data.title: Local Business Schema
local-biz-data.body:
What Is Local Business Schema?

Local Business schema is structured data that helps search engines understand your physical business location, services, and operating details. It's specifically designed for businesses that serve customers at a physical location or within a defined service area.

When to Enable Local Business Schema

Enable only if you:

  • Have a physical location customers can visit
  • Serve customers in a defined geographic area
  • Want to appear in local search and Google Maps
  • Have consistent business hours and contact information

Don't enable if you:

  • Run a purely online business with no physical presence
  • Don't serve specific geographic areas
  • Only sell digital products or services globally

Business Information Must Match

üî• Critical: If you have a Google Business Profile, your Name, Address, and Phone (NAP) must EXACTLY match between:
  • This plugin's schema settings
  • Your Google Business Profile
  • Your website footer/contact page

Inconsistent information confuses search engines and hurts local SEO.

Business Type Selection

Choose the most specific business type that matches your business. For example:

  • Don't choose "Restaurant" if you're a "FastFoodRestaurant"
  • Don't choose "Store" if you're a "ClothingStore"
  • Don't choose "Professional Service" if you're a "LegalService"

Specific types give search engines more context about your business category.

Required vs Optional Fields

Essential for Local SEO:

  • Business name
  • Complete address
  • Phone number
  • Business hours
  • Business type/category

Optional but helpful:

  • Price range ($$, $$$, etc.)
  • Payment methods accepted
  • Languages spoken
  • Service areas

Leaving optional fields empty won't harm your site, but complete information may help with local visibility.

üí° Tip: Use Google's Rich Results Test to validate your local business schema after setup.

Local Business Schema Benefits

Local Business schema may help with:

  • Appearing in "Map Pack" results
  • Showing business hours in search results
  • Displaying contact information directly
  • Better local search visibility

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Schema does not guarantee rich results or improved rankings. It helps search engines understand your business better, which may lead to better local visibility.

seo-templates.title: SEO Templates Explained
seo-templates.body:
What Are SEO Templates?

SEO templates provide automatic fallback values for page titles and meta descriptions when individual pages don't have custom SEO set.

Key point: Templates are used ONLY when per-page SEO values are missing.

How Templates Work

Priority order:

  1. Custom per-page SEO (highest priority) ‚Äî set via meta box on individual posts/pages
  2. Template (fallback) ‚Äî uses template with variables
  3. WordPress default (last resort) ‚Äî basic title from post/page title

Available Variables

Templates use variables that automatically fill with page-specific information:

  • {title} - The page or post title
  • {site} - Your site name (from General Settings)
  • {separator} - The separator character you configure (e.g., |)
  • {excerpt} - The post excerpt (if available)
  • {category} - The primary category (for posts)
  • {author} - The post author name
  • {date} - The publication date
üí° Note: You don't need to use all variables. Only use what makes sense for your site.

Common Template Examples

Simple title template:

{title} {separator} {site}

Result: "About Us | Asneris SEO Toolkit"

Blog post with category:

{title} {separator} {category} {separator} {site}

Result: "How to Use Schema | SEO Tips | Asneris SEO Toolkit"

Minimalist:

{title}

Result: Just the page title, no site name

Title Separator

The separator is the character that visually splits parts of the title. Common options:

  • | (pipe) - most common
  • - (dash)
  • ¬∑ (middle dot)
  • ‚Ä¢ (bullet)

Choose one that matches your brand style. There's no SEO advantage to any specific separator.

Description Templates

Description templates work similarly, but you can often leave them empty.

If empty: This plugin (or your theme) will automatically extract the first ~155 characters from the page content or excerpt.

If filled: The template will be used as the meta description fallback.

Example description template:

Read about {title} on {site}. {excerpt}
‚ö†Ô∏è Best Practice: For most sites, it's better to leave description templates empty and let the plugin auto-generate from content. This ensures descriptions are unique and relevant.

Per-Post Type Templates

You can set different templates for:

  • Posts
  • Pages
  • Custom post types (e.g., Products, Events)

This gives you flexibility. For example:

  • Pages: {title} | {site}
  • Posts: {title} - {category} | {site}

When Should I Use Templates?

Use templates if:

  • You have many pages and can't write custom SEO for each one
  • You want consistent title formatting across your site
  • You're okay with generic fallback descriptions

Write custom per-page SEO if:

  • The page is important (homepage, key landing pages, popular posts)
  • You want to optimize for specific keywords or phrases
  • You want compelling, unique descriptions that drive clicks

üí° Pro Tip: Start with simple templates like {title} | {site}. You can always customize important pages individually later.

Do Templates Affect Rankings?

Templates help ensure every page has a title and description. However:

  • Custom, hand-written SEO titles and descriptions usually perform better
  • Templates provide consistency but lack specificity
  • High-value pages should always have custom SEO

Think of templates as safety nets, not optimization tools.

maintenance-safety.title: Maintenance & Safety Tools
maintenance-safety.body:
What's on This Tab?

The Maintenance & Safety tab provides tools for:

  • Detecting conflicts with other SEO plugins
  • Exporting your settings as a backup
  • Importing settings from a backup
  • Resetting all plugin settings

Most users rarely need these tools unless troubleshooting issues or migrating sites.

Conflict Detection

This plugin checks for other active SEO plugins and warns you if multiple plugins might be outputting duplicate meta tags, schema, or sitemaps.

Common conflicts:

  • Multiple title tags
  • Duplicate meta descriptions
  • Conflicting canonical URLs
  • Duplicate schema markup
  • Multiple active sitemaps

‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Running multiple SEO plugins simultaneously can confuse search engines and hurt your SEO. Keep only one SEO plugin active at a time.

How to fix conflicts:

  1. Decide which SEO plugin you want to use as your primary tool
  2. Deactivate or uninstall other SEO plugins
  3. Clear your site cache (if using a caching plugin)
  4. Test a few pages to ensure meta tags appear correctly

Export Settings

Use this to download your current plugin settings as a JSON file.

When to export:

  • Before making major changes
  • Before updating WordPress or the plugin
  • Before migrating to a new hosting provider
  • As a regular backup (monthly or quarterly)

The exported file contains all your settings (verification codes, social media config, schema settings, templates, etc.) but does NOT include per-post SEO data.

Import Settings

Upload a previously exported JSON file to restore settings.

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Only import files that were exported from this plugin. Importing settings from other plugins or manually edited JSON files may cause errors.

Use cases:

  • Restoring settings after a reset
  • Cloning settings to a new site (staging, development)
  • Recovering from accidental changes

Reset Settings

This button deletes ALL plugin settings and returns everything to default.

üî• Danger: This action is PERMANENT and cannot be undone. All configuration, verification codes, schema settings, and templates will be deleted.

Use reset only if:

  • You want to start fresh with a clean configuration
  • You're troubleshooting a serious issue and need to rule out bad settings
  • You're preparing to uninstall the plugin

Before resetting: Export your settings so you can restore them later if needed.

Plugin Information

This section shows:

  • Plugin version number
  • Plugin installation path

Useful for troubleshooting or when contacting support.

üí° Pro Tip: Make it a habit to export settings before making major changes. It takes 5 seconds and can save you hours of reconfiguration if something goes wrong.

page-diagnostics-overview.title: Page Diagnostics Overview
page-diagnostics-overview.body:
What is Page Diagnostics?

Page Diagnostics is a read-only inspection tool that shows you exactly what search engines, social platforms, and browsers can read from a single page on your site.

This page reflects a single fetch at a specific point in time. Results may change if your page, settings, or server behavior changes.

What It Does

  • Fetches a page's HTML as search engines would see it
  • Extracts all SEO-relevant meta tags and structured data
  • Shows HTTP status codes and redirects
  • Displays title tags, descriptions, canonical URLs, and robots directives
  • Lists social media preview tags (Open Graph, Twitter Cards)
  • Shows structured data (schema.org JSON-LD)
Important: This tool is read-only. It shows facts about what exists ‚Äî no scoring, no recommendations, no changes.

What It Does NOT Do

  • Does not predict rankings or guarantee results
  • Does not assign quality scores
  • Does not provide content optimization suggestions
  • Does not modify your page in any way

When to Use Page Diagnostics

  • Verify SEO settings are correctly applied to a specific page
  • Troubleshoot indexing issues for individual URLs
  • Check if multiple plugins are creating duplicate tags
  • Confirm redirects are working as expected
  • Verify social preview tags before sharing
  • Inspect structured data output

How It Works

  1. Select a page from the dropdown or enter a custom URL
  2. Click "Run Diagnostics" to fetch the page
  3. Review the results in categorized sections
  4. Use findings to verify or troubleshoot settings

page-fetch-status.title: Page Fetch & HTTP Status
page-fetch-status.body:
What is Page Fetch?

Page fetch shows whether the page loads successfully and reports the HTTP status code returned by your server.

HTTP Status Codes

2xx Success:

  • 200 OK ‚Äî Page loaded successfully (most common)

3xx Redirects:

  • 301 Moved Permanently ‚Äî Page has permanently moved to a new URL
  • 302 Found ‚Äî Page temporarily redirects to another URL
  • 307 Temporary Redirect ‚Äî Similar to 302, preserves request method

4xx Client Errors:

  • 404 Not Found ‚Äî Page does not exist
  • 403 Forbidden ‚Äî Access denied
  • 410 Gone ‚Äî Page permanently removed

5xx Server Errors:

  • 500 Internal Server Error ‚Äî Server-side problem
  • 503 Service Unavailable ‚Äî Server temporarily down
Important: If a page returns 404, 500, or other error codes, search engines cannot index it ‚Äî even if it appears in your sitemap.

Redirects

If the page redirects, you'll see:

  • Tested URL: The URL you entered
  • Final URL: Where the page ultimately lands
  • Redirect Type: 301, 302, 307, etc.

Important: The Final URL is where the browser lands after redirects. It is not necessarily the canonical URL.

Note: Search engines follow redirects but may lose signals through redirect chains. Keep redirects to 1 hop when possible.

indexing-rules.title: Indexing Rules (Robots Meta)
indexing-rules.body:
What Are Indexing Rules?

Indexing rules tell search engines whether a page is allowed to appear in search results. These rules are communicated through:

  • <meta name="robots"> tags in HTML
  • X-Robots-Tag HTTP headers

Common Directives

index: Allow the page in search results (default)

noindex: Prevent the page from appearing in search results

follow: Allow search engines to follow links on the page (default)

nofollow: Do not follow links on this page

noarchive: Do not show a cached copy in search results

nosnippet: Do not show a text snippet or video preview in search results

Critical: If a page has noindex, search engines will remove it from their index (or never index it). Make sure this is intentional.

Note: Removing noindex does not instantly restore rankings ‚Äî search engines must re-crawl the page.

Multiple Robots Tags

If Page Diagnostics detects multiple robots meta tags, this indicates a conflict:

  • Multiple SEO plugins outputting tags
  • Theme and plugin both adding tags
  • Manual tags in addition to plugin-generated ones
Resolution: Search engines typically use the most restrictive directive when multiple tags exist. Fix conflicts by disabling duplicate SEO plugins.

X-Robots-Tag Header

Some sites use HTTP headers instead of meta tags. If present, Page Diagnostics will show the X-Robots-Tag value. This header has the same effect as the meta tag.

canonical-url.title: Canonical URL
canonical-url.body:
What is a Canonical URL?

A canonical URL tells search engines which version of a page to index when multiple URLs show the same (or very similar) content.

Why Canonical URLs Matter

These URLs may show the same content:

  • example.com/page
  • example.com/page/ (with trailing slash)
  • example.com/page?utm_source=email (with tracking parameters)

The canonical tag consolidates ranking signals to one preferred URL.

Canonical Tag Format

<link rel="canonical" href="https://example.com/page/" />

Common Patterns

Self-referencing canonical: Most pages should canonical to themselves (the current URL). This is the default WordPress behavior.

Cross-page canonical: Page A canonicals to Page B. This tells search engines to index Page B instead of Page A.

Important: If a page canonicals to a different URL, search engines will likely not index that page ‚Äî they'll index the canonical target instead.

Issues to Watch For

  • Multiple canonical tags: Indicates plugin conflicts (search engines use the first one)
  • Canonical to homepage: All pages pointing to homepage (loses page-level indexing)
  • Canonical to redirected URL: Target URL redirects elsewhere (creates confusion)
  • Canonical to noindex page: Target is blocked from indexing (page won't be indexed)
  • HTTP vs HTTPS mismatch: Canonical uses wrong protocol

Testing Canonical Target

Page Diagnostics will test the canonical target URL and report:

  • HTTP Status: Does the target load successfully?
  • Redirects: Does the target redirect elsewhere?
  • Indexability: Is the target allowed to be indexed?

Tip: A green "self-referencing" canonical is usually the safest and recommended setup.

WordPress Default: WordPress automatically adds a self-referencing canonical to most pages. Custom canonicals are rarely needed.

meta-tags.title: Meta Tags (Title & Description)
meta-tags.body:
Title Tag

The title tag (<title>) is what appears:

  • In search engine results as the blue clickable link
  • In browser tabs
  • When pages are shared on social media

Title Tag Best Practices

  • Keep under 60 characters (search engines may truncate longer titles)
  • Include primary keywords naturally
  • Make titles unique across pages
  • Write for humans first, search engines second
Multiple Title Tags: If Page Diagnostics detects multiple <title> tags, this indicates a conflict between your theme and plugins. Search engines typically use the first title tag.

Meta Description

The meta description is the brief text that appears below the title in search results.

Key Points About Descriptions

  • Search engines may display your description or generate their own
  • Does not directly affect rankings
  • Affects click-through rates (CTR) when shown
  • Typical display range: ~120‚Äì160 characters (varies by query and device)
Note: Google often ignores custom descriptions and generates its own based on the user's search query and page content.

Multiple Meta Tags

If Page Diagnostics shows multiple meta descriptions, this indicates:

  • Multiple SEO plugins are active
  • Theme and plugin both output descriptions
  • Manual meta tags exist in addition to plugin-generated ones

Resolution: Disable duplicate SEO plugins or remove manual meta tags. Search engines typically use the first meta description tag.

Missing Title or Description

If no custom title or description is set:

  • Title: WordPress uses the post title + site name
  • Description: May auto-generate from post excerpt or first ~30 words of content

social-preview.title: Social Media Preview Tags
social-preview.body:
What Are Social Preview Tags?

Social preview tags control how your pages look when shared on social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and messaging apps.

These tags affect how links look when shared ‚Äî they do not affect search rankings.

Open Graph (og:) Tags

Used by Facebook, LinkedIn, Discord, and most social platforms:

  • og:title ‚Äî Title shown in preview
  • og:description ‚Äî Description text
  • og:image ‚Äî Preview image
  • og:url ‚Äî Canonical URL for social sharing
  • og:type ‚Äî Content type (article, website, etc.)
  • og:site_name ‚Äî Your site's name

Twitter Card Tags

Twitter/X uses its own tags (but falls back to Open Graph if missing):

  • twitter:card ‚Äî Card type (summary, summary_large_image)
  • twitter:title ‚Äî Title for Twitter
  • twitter:description ‚Äî Description for Twitter
  • twitter:image ‚Äî Image for Twitter card
  • twitter:site ‚Äî Your Twitter username
Fallback Behavior: Most platforms will use Open Graph tags if Twitter-specific tags are missing.

Recommended Image Sizes

  • Open Graph: 1200√ó630 pixels (works on most platforms)
  • Twitter Summary: 120√ó120 pixels (minimum)
  • Twitter Large Image: 1200√ó628 pixels

Testing Social Previews

Use these official tools to see how your pages appear when shared:

  • Facebook: Sharing Debugger
  • Twitter: Card Validator
  • LinkedIn: Post Inspector
Cache Note: Social platforms cache preview data. After updating tags, use their debug tools to clear the cache and fetch fresh data.

Multiple Social Tags

If Page Diagnostics detects multiple og:title or og:image tags, this indicates plugin conflicts. Platforms typically use the first tag they encounter.

structured-data.title: Structured Data (Schema)
structured-data.body:
What is Structured Data?

Structured data (also called schema markup) is code that helps search engines understand what your content represents ‚Äî not just what it says.

Common Schema Types

  • Organization: Your company/site information
  • WebSite: Site-level data and search box
  • WebPage: Individual page information
  • BreadcrumbList: Navigation path
  • Article: Blog posts and news articles
  • Product: E-commerce products
  • LocalBusiness: Business location and hours
  • Review: Customer reviews and ratings

JSON-LD Format

Most modern structured data uses JSON-LD format, which appears in <script type="application/ld+json"> tags.

Example:

<script type="application/ld+json">
{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Organization",
  "name": "Your Company",
  "url": "https://example.com"
}
</script>
Benefits: Structured data can help search engines show rich results (star ratings, breadcrumbs, event details, etc.) in search results ‚Äî but rich results are never guaranteed.

Note: Valid structured data does not guarantee rich results. Display is entirely at the search engine's discretion.

What Page Diagnostics Shows

  • Schema Block Count: Number of JSON-LD blocks found
  • Schema Types: Which schema types are present
  • Raw JSON: Full structured data code (expandable)

Validating Structured Data

Use Google's official tools to validate schema:

  • Rich Results Test: Test Tool ‚Äî Tests for rich result eligibility
  • Schema Markup Validator: Validator ‚Äî Validates schema.org syntax
Important: Structured data improves understanding, not rankings. Rich results may appear if Google chooses to display them, but this is not guaranteed.

Multiple Schema Blocks

It's normal to have multiple JSON-LD blocks on a page (e.g., Organization + WebPage + BreadcrumbList). Each block serves a different purpose.

Missing Structured Data

If Page Diagnostics shows "No schema blocks detected":

  • The page has no structured data (not necessarily a problem)
  • Schema may be embedded in HTML attributes (Page Diagnostics only shows JSON-LD)
  • You can add structured data through plugin settings or manually

cards.title: About Site Diagnostics
cards.content:
Site Diagnostics checks site-wide SEO patterns that may affect how search engines discover, understand, and index your pages. It focuses on global signals, not individual pages.

This helps you identify issues that impact all pages at once.

cards.title: Can search engines easily discover your pages?
cards.content:
• Checks whether your XML sitemap exists and is accessible
  • Verifies HTTP status of the sitemap
  • Confirms whether the sitemap is referenced in robots.txt
  • Shows whether WordPress is managing the sitemap

Why this matters: If search engines cannot find your sitemap, they may discover pages slowly or miss updates.

cards.title: Is your site sending clear, single signals?
cards.content:
• Detects multiple active SEO plugins
  • Checks for duplicate title tags
  • Checks for duplicate meta descriptions
  • Verifies single canonical output
  • Ensures robots and schema tags are not duplicated

Why this matters: Search engines expect one clear SEO signal per page. Multiple outputs can cause confusion.

cards.title: Is anything blocking your site from search results?
cards.content:
• Checks if global noindex is enabled
  • Detects large robots.txt crawl blocks
  • Reviews sitemap accessibility
  • Samples redirect chains that may block crawling

Important: Even a well-optimized site cannot appear in search results if indexing is blocked.

cards.title: Do pages clearly identify their main URL?
cards.content:
• Detects pages canonicalizing to the homepage
  • Checks for canonical loops
  • Finds canonicals pointing to redirected URLs
  • Verifies consistent HTTP / HTTPS usage
  • Confirms default WordPress canonical behavior

Why this matters: Canonical URLs tell search engines which version of a page should be indexed.

cards.title: How to use this page
cards.content:
1. Fix blocking issues (red status) first
  2. Resolve duplicate or conflict warnings next
  3. Use Page Diagnostics for deep checks on individual URLs

cards.content:
This page shows facts and detected patterns only.

It does not predict rankings, assign scores, or guarantee results. It reflects what search engines can see at a site-wide level.

site-diagnostics-overview.title: Site Diagnostics Overview
site-diagnostics-overview.body:
What is Site Diagnostics?

Site Diagnostics performs automated checks on site-wide SEO patterns that may affect how search engines discover, crawl, and index your content.

What It Checks

  • Discovery: Can search engines find your sitemap and content?
  • Conflicts: Are multiple plugins outputting duplicate SEO tags?
  • Blocking Issues: Is anything preventing your site from appearing in search results?
  • Canonical Consistency: Are pages correctly identifying their main URL?
  • Technical Patterns: Are there redirect chains or crawl issues?
Note: Sitemaps help discovery, not rankings. They don't guarantee indexing or improve rankings directly.
Important: This tool shows facts and patterns only. It does not predict rankings, assign scores, or guarantee results.

What It Does NOT Check

  • Content quality or keyword optimization
  • Page speed or performance
  • Mobile-friendliness
  • Backlinks or domain authority
  • Individual page-level issues (use Page Diagnostics for that)

When to Run Site Diagnostics

  • After initial plugin setup
  • After major site changes (theme, plugins, settings)
  • When troubleshooting site-wide indexing issues
  • Before launching a new site
  • Periodically (monthly or quarterly)

Understanding Results

Status Indicators:

  • ‚úì Pass (Green): No issues detected
  • ‚ö† Warning (Yellow): Potential issues that may need attention
  • ‚úó Error (Red): Critical issues that may prevent indexing
  • ‚Ñπ Info (Blue): Informational notes, no action required
  • On newly launched sites, to verify nothing is blocking indexing
Priority: Fix red errors first, then address yellow warnings. Info items are for reference only.

How Long Does It Take?

Site Diagnostics runs automatically when you load the page and typically completes in a few seconds. Results are cached for performance.

sitemap-discovery.title: Sitemap Discovery & Accessibility
sitemap-discovery.body:
What is Sitemap Discovery?

Site Diagnostics checks whether your XML sitemap exists, is accessible, and is properly announced to search engines.

What Gets Checked

  • Sitemap Exists: Does your site have an XML sitemap?
  • HTTP Status: Does the sitemap return 200 OK (not 404 or redirect)?
  • Referenced in robots.txt: Is the sitemap declared in your robots.txt file?
  • Format Validity: Is the sitemap valid XML?
  • WordPress Core Sitemap: Is WordPress generating the sitemap?

Common Sitemap Locations

  • /wp-sitemap.xml ‚Äî WordPress core sitemap (default since WP 5.5)
  • /sitemap.xml ‚Äî Common SEO plugin location
  • /sitemap_index.xml ‚Äî Sitemap index (for large sites)

Why Sitemaps Matter

  • Help search engines discover new and updated pages faster
  • Provide last-modified dates for prioritization
  • Useful for large sites or sites with deep page hierarchies
  • Required for submitting to Google Search Console and Bing Webmaster Tools
Note: Sitemaps help discovery, not rankings. They don't guarantee indexing or improve rankings directly.

Common Issues & Fixes

Sitemap Not Found (404):

  • Check if WordPress core sitemap is enabled (Settings ‚Üí Reading)
  • Verify SEO plugin sitemap settings
  • Ensure only one sitemap source is active (avoid conflicts)
  • Check permalink settings (Settings ‚Üí Permalinks, save to flush)

Sitemap Not in robots.txt:

  • Add Sitemap: https://yoursite.com/sitemap.xml to robots.txt
  • Most SEO plugins add this automatically
  • Manual addition is acceptable

Multiple SEO Plugins:

  • Disable sitemap generation in all but one plugin
  • Use WordPress core sitemap if no advanced features needed
  • Check for conflicts using Site Diagnostics
Critical: If your sitemap returns 404 or redirects, search engines cannot access it ‚Äî even if it's declared in robots.txt or submitted to Search Console.

After Fixing Sitemap Issues

  1. Verify sitemap is accessible: Visit the URL directly
  2. Check robots.txt: Visit yoursite.com/robots.txt
  3. Submit sitemap to Google Search Console
  4. Submit sitemap to Bing Webmaster Tools
  5. Re-run Site Diagnostics to confirm fixes

duplicate-signals.title: Duplicate SEO Signals & Plugin Conflicts
duplicate-signals.body:
What Are Duplicate Signals?

Duplicate signals occur when multiple sources (plugins, theme, manual code) output the same type of SEO tag, creating confusion for search engines.

What Gets Checked

Site Diagnostics detects:

  • Multiple SEO Plugins: More than one active SEO plugin
  • Duplicate Title Tags: Multiple <title> tags in HTML
  • Duplicate Meta Descriptions: Multiple description tags
  • Duplicate Canonical URLs: Multiple canonical tags
  • Duplicate Robots Tags: Multiple robots meta tags
  • Duplicate Schema: Multiple Organization or WebSite schema blocks

Why This Matters

When search engines encounter duplicate tags, they typically:

  • Use the first tag they encounter (ignoring others)
  • May use the most restrictive directive (for robots tags)
  • Experience confusion about which signal is authoritative
  • May index content inconsistently
Important: Search engines expect one clear signal per page. Multiple outputs dilute clarity and can cause indexing issues.

Common Causes

  • Multiple SEO plugins active: Yoast + Rank Math + this plugin
  • Theme outputting SEO tags: Theme includes built-in SEO features
  • Manual tags in templates: Developer added manual meta tags
  • Leftover code: Old plugin code not removed after deactivation

How to Fix Conflicts

  1. Choose ONE SEO plugin as your primary tool
  2. Deactivate or uninstall other SEO plugins
  3. Check theme settings ‚Äî disable theme-based SEO features
  4. Search template files for manual meta tags (header.php, functions.php)
  5. Clear site cache after making changes
  6. Re-run Site Diagnostics to verify fixes

Detected Conflicting Plugins

Site Diagnostics will list any active SEO plugins it detects. Common conflicts include:

  • Yoast SEO
  • Rank Math SEO
  • All in One SEO Pack
  • SEOPress
  • The SEO Framework
  • Slim SEO
Recommendation: Keep only ONE SEO plugin active. This plugin is designed to work standalone or can be disabled if you prefer another SEO solution.

Testing After Fixes

Use Page Diagnostics to inspect a few pages and verify:

  • Only one title tag appears
  • Only one meta description exists
  • Only one canonical URL is set
  • Robots meta tags are singular and consistent

indexing-blocks.title: Indexing Blocks & Search Visibility
indexing-blocks.body:
What Are Indexing Blocks?

Indexing blocks are settings or directives that prevent search engines from indexing your site or specific pages, effectively hiding them from search results.

What Gets Checked

Site Diagnostics looks for:

  • Global noindex: WordPress "Discourage search engines" setting
  • Homepage noindex: Homepage blocked from indexing
  • robots.txt blocks: Overly aggressive crawl restrictions
  • Conflicting signals: Pages in sitemap but marked noindex
  • HTTP headers: X-Robots-Tag blocking indexing

WordPress "Discourage Search Engines"

Location: Settings ‚Üí Reading ‚Üí Search engine visibility

When checked, WordPress adds this to every page:

<meta name="robots" content="noindex, nofollow" />
Critical: If this setting is enabled, your entire site is blocked from search results. This setting should only be checked for development/staging sites.

How to Fix Global Noindex

  1. Go to WordPress Dashboard ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Reading
  2. Find "Search engine visibility" section
  3. Ensure "Discourage search engines from indexing this site" is UNCHECKED
  4. Click Save Changes
  5. Wait for search engines to re-crawl (typically several days, depending on crawl frequency)
  6. Request re-indexing in Google Search Console (optional but faster)

Homepage Noindex

If only your homepage is noindexed:

  • Check homepage meta box SEO settings (if editing homepage)
  • Check SEO plugin global settings for homepage rules
  • Use Page Diagnostics to inspect the homepage
  • Verify no theme code is adding noindex to the homepage

robots.txt Blocks

Site Diagnostics checks for overly broad robots.txt rules like:

  • Disallow: / ‚Äî Blocks entire site from crawling
  • Disallow: /wp-content/ ‚Äî Blocks themes, plugins, uploads
  • Missing Allow: exceptions for necessary resources
Important: robots.txt blocks crawling, not indexing. However, search engines cannot index pages they cannot crawl.

Conflicting Signals

Common conflicts detected:

  • Page in sitemap but noindexed: Tells search engines to index, then tells them not to
  • Canonical to noindexed page: Points to a page that won't be indexed
  • Redirect to noindexed page: Sends visitors to a page not in search results

Fix: Either remove the page from the sitemap OR remove the noindex tag. Both signals should agree.

Checking Individual Pages

After fixing site-wide blocks, check key pages using Page Diagnostics to verify:

  • No robots meta tag says noindex
  • No X-Robots-Tag header blocks indexing
  • Page appears in sitemap (if applicable)
  • Canonical points to itself or an indexable page

How Long Until Fixed?

After removing noindex blocks:

  • Search engines must re-crawl to see changes (typically several days, depending on crawl frequency)
  • Previously indexed pages may stay in results longer
  • New pages will begin indexing if eligible
  • Use Google Search Console to request faster re-crawling

canonical-consistency.title: Canonical URL Consistency
canonical-consistency.body:
What is Canonical Consistency?

Canonical consistency ensures pages correctly declare their preferred URL to search engines, preventing duplicate content issues and consolidating ranking signals.

What Gets Checked

Site Diagnostics checks a representative sample of pages to detect:

  • Canonical to homepage: Pages incorrectly pointing to homepage as canonical
  • Canonical loops: Page A ‚Üí B, Page B ‚Üí A (circular references)
  • Canonical to redirected URL: Canonical target redirects elsewhere
  • HTTP/HTTPS mismatches: Canonical uses wrong protocol
  • Trailing slash inconsistency: Mixed usage of trailing slashes
  • Missing canonicals: Pages without canonical tags

Understanding Canonical URLs

A canonical URL is the "main" version of a page when multiple URLs show similar content:

  • example.com/page
  • example.com/page/ (with trailing slash)
  • example.com/page?utm_source=email (with tracking)

The canonical tag tells search engines: "Index this URL, ignore the others."

WordPress Default Behavior

WordPress automatically adds a self-referencing canonical to most pages:

<link rel="canonical" href="https://example.com/current-page/" />

This is the recommended approach for most sites. Custom canonicals are rarely needed.

Best Practice: Let WordPress handle canonicals automatically unless you have a specific reason to customize them.

Common Canonical Issues

1. Canonical to Homepage

  • Problem: All pages canonical to homepage (e.g., all pages point to example.com/)
  • Impact: Search engines may only index the homepage, ignoring other pages
  • Cause: Plugin misconfiguration, theme bug, or manual error
  • Fix: Review canonical settings, check for plugin conflicts

2. Canonical Loops

  • Problem: Page A canonicals to Page B, Page B canonicals to Page A
  • Impact: Confuses search engines, may result in neither page being indexed
  • Cause: Manual canonical override errors
  • Fix: Remove custom canonical or ensure one-way canonical flow

3. Canonical to Redirected URL

  • Problem: Canonical points to a URL that redirects elsewhere
  • Impact: Creates confusion; search engines may ignore the canonical
  • Cause: Old canonical not updated after URL change
  • Fix: Update canonical to point to the final destination

4. HTTP/HTTPS Mismatch

  • Problem: Site uses HTTPS, but canonical uses HTTP (or vice versa)
  • Impact: Splits ranking signals between two versions
  • Cause: Incorrect site URL in WordPress settings
  • Fix: Update WordPress settings (Settings ‚Üí General ‚Üí WordPress Address URL and Site Address URL)
Critical: If a page canonicals to a different URL, search engines will likely not index that page ‚Äî they'll index the canonical target instead.

How to Fix Canonical Issues

  1. Use Page Diagnostics to inspect affected pages
  2. Check WordPress Settings ‚Üí General (ensure correct HTTPS/HTTP)
  3. Review per-page canonical settings in SEO meta box
  4. Check for plugin conflicts (multiple SEO plugins)
  5. Verify theme isn't adding conflicting canonical tags
  6. Clear site cache after making changes
  7. Re-run Site Diagnostics to confirm fixes

When to Use Custom Canonicals

Only use custom canonicals when:

  • Consolidating duplicate content (e.g., print version ‚Üí main version)
  • Handling URL parameters that don't change content
  • Managing paginated series (page 2+ ‚Üí page 1)

For most sites, WordPress default canonicals are sufficient and safer.

redirect-chains.title: Redirect Chains & Performance
redirect-chains.body:
Note: Site Diagnostics identifies the presence of redirect chain patterns. Detailed per-URL analysis is available in Page Diagnostics.

What Are Redirect Chains?

A redirect chain occurs when a URL redirects multiple times before reaching the final destination. For example:

Page A ‚Üí Page B ‚Üí Page C ‚Üí Final Page

Each hop adds latency and may cause search engines to stop following the chain.

What Gets Checked

Site Diagnostics checks a representative sample of pages to detect:

  • Redirect chains: URLs with 2+ redirect hops
  • Redirect loops: URLs that redirect back to themselves (infinite loops)
  • Redirects to 404s: Redirect destination doesn't exist
  • Redirects to noindex pages: Final destination blocked from indexing
  • Mixed HTTP/HTTPS redirects: Unnecessary protocol redirects

Why Redirect Chains Matter

  • Slow user experience: Each redirect adds load time
  • Wasted crawl budget: Search engines may stop after 3-5 hops
  • Lost signals: Each hop may dilute ranking signals
  • Indexing issues: Long chains may prevent indexing entirely
Important: Google and other search engines may not follow redirect chains longer than 5 hops. Pages at the end of long chains may not be indexed.

Common Causes of Redirect Chains

  • Multiple URL changes: Page moved multiple times without cleaning up old redirects
  • HTTP ‚Üí HTTPS + www: Protocol redirect + subdomain redirect
  • Plugin conflicts: Multiple redirect sources (server, plugin, theme)
  • Manual redirects + automatic redirects: Overlapping redirect rules

How to Fix Redirect Chains

  1. Identify the final destination: Follow the chain to see where it ends
  2. Update redirect to point directly: Skip intermediate hops
  3. Example: If A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C, change to A ‚Üí C (direct)
  4. Remove unnecessary redirects: If a page no longer needs to redirect, remove the rule
  5. Consolidate redirect sources: Use ONE redirect management tool
  6. Clear server cache and CDN cache after changes
  7. Test with Page Diagnostics or browser tools

Redirect Loops

A redirect loop occurs when a URL redirects back to itself:

Page A ‚Üí Page B ‚Üí Page A (infinite loop)
Critical: Redirect loops make pages completely inaccessible to both users and search engines. Fix immediately.

How to fix:

  1. Identify which page redirects back to itself
  2. Check redirect rules in SEO plugin or .htaccess
  3. Remove the conflicting redirect rule
  4. Verify the page loads correctly after fix

Redirects to 404s

If a redirect points to a non-existent page:

  • Problem: Users see 404 error after redirect
  • Impact: Bad user experience, page won't be indexed
  • Fix: Update redirect to point to an existing, relevant page

Best Practices for Redirects

  • Always redirect directly: A ‚Üí C (not A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C)
  • Use 301 for permanent moves: Tells search engines to transfer signals
  • Test after creating redirects: Verify they work as expected
  • Clean up old redirects: Remove redirects that are no longer needed (after 6-12 months)
  • Avoid redirect loops: Never redirect back to the original URL
  • Limit chain length: Keep redirects to 1 hop maximum

Testing Redirects

Use these tools to test redirect behavior:

  • Page Diagnostics: Shows redirect chains and final destination
  • Browser DevTools: Network tab shows all redirects
  • Online tools: Redirect checker tools (e.g., redirect-checker.org)
  • cURL command: curl -I -L https://yoursite.com/page

After Fixing Chains

  1. Test the URL directly in a browser
  2. Verify with Page Diagnostics
  3. Re-run Site Diagnostics to confirm
  4. Monitor Google Search Console for crawl errors
  5. Clear any CDN or server-level caching

cards.title: About SEO Bulk Edit
cards.content:
Bulk Edit lets you update SEO titles, descriptions, and indexing settings for multiple posts at once.

This is useful when cleaning up old content or applying consistent SEO rules.

cards.title: How to use Bulk Edit
cards.content:
• Filter by post type (Posts, Pages, etc.)
  • Optionally filter by indexing status
  • Select the items you want to change
  • Apply a bulk action or edit fields inline

cards.title: Bulk actions explained
cards.content:
• ‚úì Allow in Search (Index): Allow selected pages to appear in search results
  • ‚úó Hide from Search (NoIndex): Prevent selected pages from appearing in search results
  • Clear SEO Titles: Removes custom titles and reverts to automatic generation (uses template if configured, otherwise uses post title)
  • Clear Descriptions: Removes custom descriptions and allows auto-generation (priority: template ‚Üí post excerpt ‚Üí first 30 words of content)

üí° Tip: Clearing values doesn't delete content ‚Äî it tells the system to generate them automatically using fallback rules.

cards.title: Best practices
cards.content:
• Make small, controlled changes
  • Avoid using the same title across many pages
  • Use Noindex carefully ‚Äî it removes pages from search results
  • Review a few updated pages in Page Diagnostics after saving

cards.title: Important notes
cards.content:
• Changes are applied only after clicking Save All Changes
  • Bulk edits affect many pages ‚Äî double-check selections
  • This tool does not change content, only SEO metadata

bulk-overview.title: SEO Bulk Edit Overview
bulk-overview.body:
What is SEO Bulk Edit?

SEO Bulk Edit lets you update Content Titles, Content Descriptions, and Search Visibility (Index/NoIndex) for multiple items at once. This helps when cleaning up older content or applying consistent SEO rules across many pages.

How to Use

  1. Filter Content: Choose a Content Type (Posts, Pages, etc.) and optionally filter by Indexing Status
  2. Select Items: Check the boxes next to the items you want to update
  3. Apply Changes: Use Quick Bulk Actions or edit fields inline
  4. Save: Click Save All Changes to commit the edits

What You Can Edit

  • Custom Content Title: Set or clear the SEO title used in search results
  • Custom Content Description: Set or clear the meta description
  • Search Visibility: Control whether items are allowed to appear in search (Index/NoIndex)
Important: Nothing is applied until you click Save All Changes. Bulk edits can affect many pages‚Äîdouble-check selections before saving.

Best Practices

  • Make small, controlled changes first
  • Avoid using the same title across many pages
  • Use NoIndex carefully‚Äîit can remove pages from search results after re-crawling
  • After saving, verify a few pages using Page Diagnostics
  • Clearing values does not delete content‚Äîit tells the plugin to use automatic fallback rules

quick-bulk-actions.title: Quick Bulk Actions
quick-bulk-actions.body:
What Are Quick Bulk Actions?

These buttons apply one change to all selected items. First select rows using the checkboxes, then click an action.

‚úì Allow in Search (Index)

Allows selected items to appear in search results.

  • Outputs indexing-allowed robots rules (Index)
  • Use for normal public content

‚úó Hide from Search (NoIndex)

Prevents selected items from appearing in search results.

  • Adds noindex to the page output
  • Pages remain accessible via direct URL
  • Removal happens after search engines re-crawl
Important: NoIndex removes pages from search results, but it does not block visitors from viewing the page.

Clear Content Titles

Removes custom titles from selected items.

  • Reverts to automatic title generation
  • Useful when titles are outdated or inconsistent

Clear Descriptions

Removes custom descriptions from selected items.

  • Reverts to automatic description generation
  • Useful when descriptions are outdated, duplicated, or low quality

How to Use

  1. Filter content (optional)
  2. Select rows using checkboxes
  3. Click an action button
  4. Review updates in the table
  5. Click Save All Changes to commit

Reminder: Nothing is saved until you click Save All Changes.

filter-content.title: Filter Content
filter-content.body:
Use filters to narrow the table before making bulk updates.

  • Content Type: Choose Posts, Pages, or other content types
  • Indexing Status: Filter by Index / NoIndex (optional)
  • Click Filter to refresh the table
Tip: Always filter first before bulk NoIndex actions to avoid updating the wrong content type.

seo-title-field.title: Custom Content Title
seo-title-field.body:
What is the Custom Content Title?

This is the SEO title (title tag) that may appear as the clickable headline in search results and browser tabs.

How to Use

  • Edit inline: Type directly in the field
  • Leave blank: Uses automatic generation
  • Clear in bulk: Use Clear Content Titles to remove custom titles across selected items

Best Practices

  • Keep titles concise (often truncated if too long)
  • Make titles unique across pages
  • Reflect the page content clearly‚Äîavoid misleading titles
Note: Titles help clarity and clicks, but they do not guarantee rankings.

meta-description-field.title: Custom Content Description
meta-description-field.body:
What is the Custom Content Description?

This is the meta description that may appear under the title in search results. Search engines may use it‚Äîor generate their own snippet depending on the query.

How to Use

  • Edit inline: Type directly in the field
  • Leave blank: Uses automatic generation
  • Clear in bulk: Use Clear Descriptions to remove custom descriptions across selected items

Best Practices

  • Write a clear summary of the page
  • Avoid duplication across many pages
  • Keep it concise and readable
Tip: Prioritize custom descriptions for important pages; let less important pages auto-generate.

indexing-status.title: Search Visibility (Index / NoIndex)
indexing-status.body:
What is Search Visibility?

This controls whether a page is allowed to appear in search results.

Options

  • Index: Allowed to appear in search results
  • NoIndex: Blocked from appearing in search results
Important: NoIndex does not hide the page from visitors. It only affects search engine indexing.

When Changes Take Effect

Search engines must re-crawl pages to observe changes, so updates may take days or longer to reflect in search results.

cards.title: About SEO Redirects
cards.content:
Redirects guide visitors and search engines from an old URL to the correct page when URLs change.

This helps avoid broken links and preserves search visibility.

cards.title: How redirects work
cards.content:
• Visitors are automatically sent from the old URL to the new one
  • Search engines update their records over time
  • The original URL does not show content anymore

Why this matters: Without redirects, users may see errors and search engines may drop old pages.

cards.title: Choosing the right redirect type
cards.content:
• 301 (Permanent): Use when a page has moved permanently (recommended for SEO)
  • 302 / 307 (Temporary): Use when the change is short-term and the original page will return

Tip: Temporary redirects keep the original URL indexed.

cards.title: Best practices
cards.content:
• Always test the old URL after adding a redirect
  • Avoid redirect chains (URL A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C)
  • Remove redirects that are no longer needed
  • Use relative paths when redirecting within the same site

cards.title: Important Note
cards.content:
This tool manages redirects only.

It does not modify page content, predict rankings, or guarantee SEO improvements.

redirects-overview.title: What Are Redirects?
redirects-overview.body:
Purpose

Redirects automatically send visitors and search engines from one URL to another. Use them when:

  • A page's URL changes (permalink updated)
  • Content moves to a new location
  • You delete a page but want visitors to see related content
  • You're consolidating similar pages
Important: Redirects help search engines understand that a page has moved, instead of treating it as missing or deleted.

Automatic Redirects

This plugin automatically creates 301 redirects when you change a published post's permalink. Manual redirects give you full control for other scenarios.

When NOT to Use Redirects

  • Don't redirect pages that still exist at their original URL
  • Don't create redirect chains (A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C). Use direct redirects (A ‚Üí C)
  • Don't redirect to unrelated content

from-url.title: From (Old URL)
from-url.body:
What to Enter

Enter the old URL path that visitors or search engines might request. Do not include your domain name.

Supported Formats

  • /old-page/ - Pretty permalink
  • /old-page - Without trailing slash
  • /?page_id=123 - Query string format
  • /category/old-post/ - With path segments
Tip: You can copy the URL from your browser and remove the http://yoursite.com part.

Example

If your old page was:
https://example.com/old-page/

Enter only:
/old-page/

to-url.title: To (New URL)
to-url.body:
What to Enter

Enter the new URL where visitors should land. You can use:

Supported Formats

  • /new-page/ - Internal page (recommended)
  • /?page_id=456 - Query string format
  • https://example.com/page/ - Full URL for external sites
Important: Make sure the destination page exists and is accessible. Redirecting to a broken page creates a bad user experience.

Example

If your new page is:
https://example.com/new-page/

You can enter:
/new-page/

External Redirects

To redirect to another domain, use the full URL:
https://otherdomain.com/page/

redirect-types.title: Redirect Types (301, 302, 307)
redirect-types.body:
301 Permanent (Most Common)

Use when the old page is permanently replaced by the new page.

  • Tells search engines: "This page moved permanently"
  • Preserves existing signals for the new URL
  • Browsers may cache this redirect

Use for: Permalink changes, content consolidation, deleted pages

302 Temporary

Use when the redirect is temporary and the old URL may come back.

  • Tells search engines: "This is temporary, check back later"
  • Does not transfer signals to the new URL
  • Less likely to be cached

Use for: Maintenance pages, A/B testing, seasonal content

307 Temporary (Preserve Method)

Similar to 302, but guarantees that POST requests stay as POST (not converted to GET).

Use for: Form submissions, API endpoints (rare for most sites)

Recommendation: When in doubt, use 301 Permanent. It's the right choice for 95% of scenarios.

Important

Redirects preserve existing value. They do not improve rankings or create new value.

cards.title: About Validation
cards.content:
Validation checks your site for common SEO issues that may affect how search engines discover, crawl, and index your content.

It looks for clarity issues ‚Äî not rankings or guarantees.

cards.title: What Validation Checks
cards.content:
• Indexing Status: Are pages marked noindex when they shouldn't be?
  • Canonical URLs: Are pages correctly identifying their main URL?
  • Redirects: Are redirect chains or loops blocking access?
  • Sitemap: Is your sitemap accessible and referenced correctly?
  • Robots.txt: Is your robots.txt blocking critical content?

cards.title: How to Use Validation
cards.content:
1. Click Run Validation to scan your site
  2. Review results by category (errors, warnings, info)
  3. Fix errors first (red status)
  4. Address warnings as needed (yellow status)
  5. Re-run validation after making changes

cards.title: Understanding Results
cards.content:
• Error (Red): Blocking issues that prevent search engines from accessing content
  • Warning (Yellow): Potential issues that may affect clarity or discovery
  • Info (Blue): Informational notes with no immediate action needed
  • Success (Green): No issues detected

cards.title: Important Note
cards.content:
Validation shows facts and detected patterns ‚Äî not rankings or scores.

Fixing all issues does not guarantee improved rankings. It ensures your site sends clear, consistent signals to search engines.

validation-overview.title: Validation Overview
validation-overview.body:
What is Validation?

Validation is an automated scan that checks your WordPress site for common SEO issues that may prevent search engines from properly discovering, crawling, and indexing your content.

What Validation Does

  • Scans site-wide SEO patterns
  • Detects blocking issues (errors)
  • Identifies potential problems (warnings)
  • Provides informational notes
  • Groups results by category for easier review

What Validation Does NOT Do

  • Predict or guarantee rankings
  • Assign quality scores
  • Provide content recommendations
  • Check keyword optimization
  • Measure page speed or performance
Purpose: Validation ensures your site sends clear, consistent signals to search engines. It identifies technical barriers, not content quality.

When to Run Validation

  • After initial plugin setup
  • After major site changes (theme, plugins)
  • When troubleshooting indexing issues
  • Before launching a new site
  • Periodically (monthly or quarterly)

How Long Does It Take?

Validation typically takes 30-60 seconds depending on site size and complexity.

indexing-checks.title: Indexing Status Checks
indexing-checks.body:
What Are Indexing Checks?

Indexing checks verify that pages intended to appear in search results are not accidentally blocked by noindex tags or settings.

Common Issues Detected

  • Global noindex enabled: WordPress setting "Discourage search engines" is active (blocks entire site)
  • Homepage noindex: Your homepage is marked noindex
  • Key pages noindex: Important pages (products, posts) are accidentally blocked
  • Conflicting signals: Page is in sitemap but marked noindex

Why This Matters

If a page is marked noindex:

  • Search engines will remove it from their index (if already indexed)
  • Search engines will not index it (if new)
  • The page is still publicly accessible, just not in search results
Critical: If your entire site is noindexed, it will disappear from search results entirely.

How to Fix

  1. Check WordPress Settings ‚Üí Reading ‚Üí "Discourage search engines" (should be unchecked)
  2. Check individual pages in Bulk Edit for noindex status
  3. Verify plugin settings don't have global noindex enabled
  4. Check for theme or other plugin conflicts
Note: It may take days or weeks for search engines to re-crawl and re-index pages after fixing noindex issues.

canonical-checks.title: Canonical URL Checks
canonical-checks.body:
What Are Canonical Checks?

Canonical checks verify that pages correctly declare their main URL version to search engines, preventing duplicate content issues.

What is a Canonical URL?

A canonical URL is the "preferred" version of a page when multiple URLs show the same content. For example:

  • example.com/page
  • example.com/page/ (with trailing slash)
  • example.com/page?utm_source=email (with tracking)

All three may show the same content, but the canonical tells search engines which one to index.

Common Issues Detected

  • Canonical to homepage: Pages incorrectly canonical to the homepage (loses page-level indexing)
  • Canonical loops: Page A canonicals to B, B canonicals to A (confuses search engines)
  • Canonical to redirected URL: Canonical points to a URL that redirects elsewhere
  • HTTP/HTTPS mismatch: Canonical uses wrong protocol (http vs https)
  • Missing canonical: No canonical tag present (WordPress should add automatically)
Important: If a page canonicals to a different URL, search engines will likely not index that page ‚Äî they'll index the canonical URL instead.

Why This Matters

  • Prevents duplicate content issues
  • Consolidates ranking signals to one URL
  • Ensures search engines index the correct version

How to Fix

  1. Use Page Diagnostics to check canonical URLs for affected pages
  2. Verify custom canonical settings in page editor
  3. Check for plugin conflicts (multiple SEO plugins)
  4. Ensure redirects don't create canonical conflicts
WordPress Default: WordPress automatically adds a canonical to the current URL for most pages. Custom canonicals are rarely needed.

discovery-checks.title: Discovery & Crawling Checks
discovery-checks.body:
What Are Discovery Checks?

Discovery checks verify that search engines can find and crawl your pages efficiently through sitemaps and robots.txt.

Sitemap Checks

Validation verifies:

  • Sitemap exists and is accessible (e.g., /sitemap.xml)
  • Sitemap is referenced in robots.txt
  • Sitemap returns HTTP 200 (not 404 or redirect)
  • Sitemap is valid XML format

Why Sitemaps Matter

  • Help search engines discover pages faster
  • Notify search engines of new or updated content
  • Provide last-modified dates for prioritization
  • Especially important for large or deep sites
Note: Sitemaps help discovery, not rankings. They don't guarantee indexing or improve rankings directly.

Robots.txt Checks

Validation verifies:

  • robots.txt is accessible
  • No critical content is accidentally blocked
  • Sitemap is declared in robots.txt
  • No syntax errors preventing crawling

Common Issues Detected

  • Sitemap not found: Returns 404 error
  • Sitemap not in robots.txt: Not declared, may be harder for bots to find
  • robots.txt blocks sitemap: Sitemap URL itself is blocked
  • Overly broad blocking: robots.txt blocks important content

How to Fix

  1. Verify sitemap exists: Visit yoursite.com/sitemap.xml
  2. Add sitemap to robots.txt if missing
  3. Review robots.txt rules in Robots.txt Editor
  4. Submit sitemap to Google Search Console and Bing Webmaster Tools
Critical: If robots.txt blocks your sitemap or key pages, search engines cannot crawl them ‚Äî even if they're not noindexed.

redirect-checks.title: Redirect & Performance Checks
redirect-checks.body:
What Are Redirect Checks?

Redirect checks identify issues with redirects that may slow crawling, waste crawl budget, or prevent indexing entirely.

Common Issues Detected

  • Redirect chains: URL A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C ‚Üí D (multiple hops)
  • Redirect loops: URL A ‚Üí B ‚Üí A (infinite loop)
  • Redirects to noindex pages: Redirect destination is blocked from indexing
  • Redirects to 404s: Redirect points to a page that doesn't exist

Why This Matters

  • Chains waste crawl budget: Search engines may stop following after 3-5 hops
  • Loops prevent access: Page becomes uncrawlable
  • Signals may be lost: Each redirect hop may dilute ranking signals
  • Slow page loads: Each redirect adds latency for users
Important: If a redirect chain ends in a noindex page or 404, search engines may not index the final URL (or any URL in the chain).

How to Fix

  1. Review detected redirect chains in Validation results
  2. Update redirects to point directly to the final destination
  3. Remove redirect loops entirely
  4. Verify final destinations are indexable (not noindex)
  5. Use Page Diagnostics to confirm redirect behavior

Redirect Best Practices

  • Always redirect directly to the final destination
  • Use 301 (permanent) for most scenarios
  • Avoid redirect chains longer than 1 hop
  • Regularly audit old redirects (remove unnecessary ones)
Tool Tip: Use the Redirects page to manage redirects and avoid creating chains.

cards.title: About robots.txt
cards.content:
The robots.txt file tells search engines which parts of your site they are allowed to visit.

It controls crawling only ‚Äî not rankings or indexing.

cards.title: What robots.txt does (and doesn‚Äôt do)
cards.content:
• Controls which URLs search engines can crawl
  • Does not control rankings
  • Does not hide pages from the public

Important: Pages blocked here may still appear in search results if linked elsewhere.

cards.title: Common safe rules
cards.content:
• Block /wp-admin/ except admin-ajax.php
  • Block /wp-includes/ system files
  • Allow all public content
  • Include your sitemap URL

These defaults are safe for most WordPress sites.

cards.title: When to be careful
cards.content:
• Do not block CSS or JavaScript needed for page rendering
  • Do not use robots.txt to hide sensitive or private content
  • Avoid blocking entire sections unless necessary

Incorrect rules can prevent search engines from understanding your pages.

cards.title: After making changes
cards.content:
• Save the file and view the live robots.txt
  • Test important pages using Page Diagnostics
  • Re-check crawling status in Google Search Console

robots-overview.title: robots.txt Overview
robots-overview.body:
What is robots.txt?

The robots.txt file is a publicly accessible text file located at the root of your site (for example, https://example.com/robots.txt). It tells search engine crawlers which URLs they are allowed or not allowed to crawl.

Key Points

  • Controls crawling, not indexing or rankings
  • Does not hide content from users
  • Does not guarantee pages won‚Äôt appear in search results
  • Best used sparingly to avoid accidental crawl blocking
Best Practice: Use robots.txt only for crawl management. Avoid blocking URLs you want search engines to understand.

Common Uses

  • Block admin areas (e.g. /wp-admin/)
  • Block system paths (e.g. /wp-includes/)
  • Reduce crawling of duplicate or low-value URLs

Security & Privacy Note

robots.txt is public. Anyone can view it by visiting /robots.txt.

robots.txt is a crawler directive, not a security mechanism. To actually restrict access:

  • Hide from search: Use noindex meta tags
  • Restrict visitors: Use authentication or passwords
  • Protect sensitive data: Store outside the web root

robots-validation.title: robots.txt Validation Checks
robots-validation.body:
What Is Being Validated?

This section checks whether search engines can successfully access your robots.txt file.

Checks Performed

  • robots.txt file found: Confirms the file exists at /robots.txt
  • HTTP 200 response: Confirms the file is accessible without errors

Common Issues

  • HTTP instead of HTTPS: The file exists but is served over HTTP
  • Redirects: robots.txt should return directly, not redirect
  • Server restrictions: Firewalls or hosting rules blocking access
Important: Validation checks the live public URL, not what is currently typed in the editor.

After saving changes, re-run validation to confirm search engines can access the updated file.

robots-editor.title: Edit robots.txt
robots-editor.body:
What Does This Editor Do?

This editor lets you modify the robots.txt file that is served to search engines.

How It Works

  • Edits apply only after clicking Save robots.txt
  • View Live File shows what search engines currently see
  • Validation always checks the live file, not unsaved changes
Tip: After saving, always click View Live File and re-run validation to confirm the update.

What This Does NOT Do

  • Does not force indexing or rankings
  • Does not block public access to URLs
  • Does not protect sensitive data

robots-syntax.title: robots.txt Syntax Guide
robots-syntax.body:
Basic Rule Format

User-agent: [crawler name]
Disallow: [path]
Allow: [path]

User-agent

  • * ‚Äî applies to all crawlers
  • Googlebot ‚Äî Google only
  • Bingbot ‚Äî Bing only

Disallow

  • Disallow: /private/ ‚Äî blocks a directory
  • Disallow: /file.html ‚Äî blocks a file
  • Disallow: (empty) ‚Äî allows all paths

Allow

  • Overrides a broader disallow rule
  • Example: Allow: /wp-admin/admin-ajax.php

Sitemap

  • Sitemap: https://example.com/sitemap.xml
Note: Paths are case-sensitive and must be exact.

robots-best-practices.title: robots.txt Best Practices
robots-best-practices.body:
Safe WordPress Defaults

User-agent: *
Disallow: /wp-admin/
Allow: /wp-admin/admin-ajax.php
Disallow: /wp-includes/

Sitemap: https://yoursite.com/sitemap.xml

Recommended Blocks

  • Admin dashboards
  • System directories
  • Internal search results

Do NOT Block

  • CSS or JavaScript files
  • Images you want indexed
  • Main public content
Tip: Blocking resources needed for rendering can harm search engine understanding.

Common Mistakes

  • Using Disallow: / unintentionally
  • Trying to hide sensitive data with robots.txt
  • Blocking assets required for mobile rendering
